column1: Klagenfurt am Wörthersee (German: [ˌklaːɡn̩fʊʁt ʔam ˈvœʁtɐzeː] (listen); Bavarian: Klognfurt; Slovene: Celovec ob Vrbskem jezeru)
column2: usually known as just Klagenfurt (English:  KLAH-gən-foort)
column3: is the capital of the federal state of Carinthia in Austria. With a population of 101
column5: it is the sixth-largest city in the country. The city is the bishop's seat of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Gurk-Klagenfurt and home to the University of Klagenfurt
column6: the Carinthian University of Applied Sciences and the Gustav Mahler University of Music.

column1: == Geography ==
=== Location ===
The city of Klagenfurt is in southern Austria
column3: near the international border. It is in the lower middle of Austria
column4: almost the same distance from Innsbruck in the west
column5: as it is from Vienna in the northeast.

column1: Klagenfurt is elevated 446 metres (1
column2: 463 feet) above sea level and covers an area of 120.03 square kilometres (46.34 sq mi). It is on the lake Wörthersee and on the Glan river.  The city is surrounded by several forest-covered hills and mountains with heights of up to 1
column4: 300 ft) (for example Ulrichsberg). To the south of the city is the Karawanken mountain range
column5: which separates Carinthia from bordering nations of Slovenia and Italy.

column1: === Municipal arrangement ===
Klagenfurt is a statutory city of Carinthia
column2: and the administrative seat of the district of Klagenfurt-Land
column3: but is a separate district from Klagenfurt-Land. In fact
column4: their licence plates are different (K for the city
column5: KL for the district). Klagenfurt is divided itself into 16 districts:

column1: It is further divided into 25 Katastralgemeinden. They are: Klagenfurt
column5: Großbuch
column6: Großponfeld

column1: === Climate ===
Klagenfurt has a typical continental climate
column2: with a fair amount of fog throughout the autumn and winter. The rather cold winters are
column4: broken up by occasional warmer periods due to foehn wind from the Karawanken mountains to the south.  The average temperature from 1961 and 1990 was 7.1 °C (44.8 °F)
column5: while the average temperature in 2005 was 9.3 °C (48.7 °F).

column1: == Name ==
Carinthia's eminent linguists Primus Lessiak and Eberhard Kranzmayer assumed that the city's name
column2: which literally translates as "ford of lament" or "ford of complaints"
column3: had something to do with the superstitious thought that fateful fairies or demons tend to live around treacherous waters or swamps. In Old Slovene
column4: cviljovec is a place haunted by such a wailing female ghost or cvilya. Thus
column5: they assumed that Klagenfurt's name was a translation made by the German settlers of the original Slovene name of the neighbouring wetland. However
column6: the earliest Slovene mention of Klagenfurt in the form of "v Zelouzi" ('in Celovec'
column9: is 400 years more recent and thus could be a translation from German. The latest interpretation
column11: is that the Old Slovene cviljovec itself goes back to an Italic l'aquiliu meaning a place at or in the water
column12: which would make the wailing-hag theory obsolete.Scholars had at various times attempted to explain the city's peculiar name: In the 14th century
column13: the abbot and historiographer John of Viktring translated Klagenfurt's name in his Liber certarum historiarum  as Queremoniae Vadus
column16: Master of the university college of the Carinthian Estates in Klagenfurt and editor of the earliest printed history of the duchy in 1612
column17: believed to have found the origin of the name in a "ford across the River Glan"
column20: is impossible for linguistic reasons. The common people also sought an explanation: A baker's apprentice was accused of theft and executed
column21: but when a few days afterwards the alleged theft turned out to be a mistake and the lad was proved to be totally innocent
column22: the citizens' "lament" ('Klagen') went forth and forth". This story was reported by Aeneas Silvius Piccolomini
column23: who later became Pope Pius II.In 2007

column26: since there are no other settlements by the name of Klagenfurt anywhere
column27: the previous shorter name remains ubiquitous.

column1: == History ==
Legend has it that Klagenfurt was founded after a couple of brave men slayed the abominable "Lindwurm" (a winged dragon in the moors adjoining the lake
column2: the staple diet of which was said to have been virgins). The legend says that the dragon was defeated by a fat bull on a chain that the men had mounted on a strong tower. The feat is commemorated by a grandiose 9-ton Renaissance monument in the city centre.

column1: Historically
column2: the place was founded by the Spanheim Duke Herman as a stronghold sited across the commercial routes in the area. Its first mention dates from the late 12th century in a document in which Duke Ulric II. exempted St. Paul's Abbey from the toll charge "in foro Chlagenvurth". That settlement occupied an area that was subject to frequent flooding
column5: moved it to a safer position and is thus considered to be the actual founder of the market place
column6: which in 1252 received a city charter.

column1: In the following centuries
column5: and attacks from Islamic Ottomans
column6: and was ravaged by the Peasants' Wars. In 1514
column7: a fire almost completely destroyed the city
column10: despite the loud protests of the citizens
column12: the nobility of the Duchy. Never before had such a thing happened. The new owners
column14: brought about an economic renaissance and the political and cultural ascendancy in Klagenfurt. A canal was dug to connect the city to the lake as a supply route for timber to rebuild the city and to feed the city's new moats; the noble families had their town-houses built in the duchy's new capital; the city was enlarged along a geometrical chequer-board lay-out according to the Renaissance ideas of the Italian architect Domenico dell'Allio; a new city centre square
column16: was constructed; and the new fortifications that took half a century to build made Klagenfurt the strongest fortress north of the Alps.

column3: the French troops (under Napoleon) destroyed the city walls
column5: against a large sum collected by the citizens
column6: only one eastern gate (which was pulled down to make way for traffic some decades later)
column7: and the small stretch in the west which is now all that is left of the once grand fortifications. In 1863
column8: the railway connection to St. Veit an der Glan boosted the city's economy and so did the building of the Vienna-Trieste railway that brought to the city an imposing central station (destroyed in World War II) and solidified Klagenfurt as the centre of the region.

column1: Nevertheless

column2: Klagenfurt's population suddenly grew by more than 50% through the incorporation of the town of St. Ruprecht and the municipalities of St. Peter
column4: and St. Martin. But during World War II
column5: the city was bombed 41 times. The bombs killed 612 people
column6: completely destroyed 443 buildings and damaged 1
column10: 613 cu ft) of rubble had to be removed before the citizens could set about rebuilding their city.

column1: In order to avoid further destruction and a major bloodshed
column2: on 3 May 1945 General Löhr of Army Group E (Heeresgruppe E) agreed to declare Klagenfurt an "open city"  "in case Anglo-American forces should attack the city"
column3: a declaration that was broadcast several times and two days later also published in the Kärntner Nachrichten.On 8 May 1945
column5: British troops of the Eighth Army under General McCreery entered Klagenfurt and were met in front of Stauderhaus by the new democratic city and state authorities. All the strategic positions and important buildings were immediately seized
column6: and Major General Horatius Murray was taken to General Noeldechen for the official surrender of the 438th German Division. Three hours later
column7: groups of partisan forces arrived on a train they had seized in the Rosental valley the day before

column9: and masses of soldiers of all the nationalities that had been fighting under German command and were now fleeing the Russians. These partisan and Yugoslave regular forces claimed the city and the surrounding South Carinthian land

column2: Klagenfurt became the first city in Austria to adopt a pedestrian zone. The idea of a friendly twinning of cities in other countries began with the very first-ever city partnership between Klagenfurt and Wiesbaden

column7: which is a record for a European city.

== Economy ==
Klagenfurt is the economic centre of Carinthia
column2: with 20% of the industrial companies. In May 2001
column5: 184 companies here. 33 of these companies employed more than 200 people. The prevalent economic sectors are light industry
column6: electronics
column7: and tourism. There are also several printing offices.

column1: == Transport ==
Klagenfurt Airport is a primary international airport with connections to several major European cities and holiday resorts abroad.
The Klagenfurt central station (German: Hauptbahnhof) is located south of the city centre.

The city is situated at the intersection of the A2 and S37 motorways. The A2 autobahn runs from Vienna via Graz and Klagenfurt to Villach and further to the state border of Italy. The S37 freeway runs from Vienna via Bruck an der Mur and Sankt Veit an der Glan to Klagenfurt. The Loibl Pass highway B91 goes to Ljubljana
column3: which is only 88 km (55 mi) from Klagenfurt.

column1: The volume of traffic in Klagenfurt is high (motorisation level: 572 cars/1000 inhabitants in 2007).
In the 1960s
column2: with the last streetcar (tram) line demolished
column3: Klagenfurt was meant to become a car-friendly city
column4: with many wide roads. A motorway was even planned which was to cross the city partly underground
column5: but which now by-passes the city to the north. The problem of four railway lines from north
column6: west
column8: and east meeting at the central station south of the city centre and strangulating city traffic has been eased by a considerable number of underpasses on the main arteries. Nevertheless
column10: traffic jams are frequent nowadays as in most cities of similar size. Ideas of a rapid transport system using the existing railway rails
column11: of an elevated cable railway to the football stadium
column12: or of a regular motorboat service on the Lend Canal from the city centre to the lake have not materialized. But for those who fancy leisurely travel there is a regular motorboat and steamer service on the lake connecting the resorts on Wörthersee. During severe winters
column14: you might of course be faster crossing the frozen lake on your skates.

column1: == Culture ==
There is a civic theatre-cum-opera house with professional companies
column3: a state conservatory and concert hall. There are musical societies such as Musikverein (founded in 1826) or Mozartgemeinde
column5: the State Museum
column6: a modern art museum and the Diocesan museum of religious art; the Artists' House
column7: two municipal and several private galleries
column9: literary institutions such as the Robert Musil House
column10: and a reputable German-literature competition awarding the prestigious Ingeborg Bachmann Prize.

column1: Klagenfurt is the home of a number of small but fine publishing houses
column2: and several papers or regional editions are also published here including dailies such as "Kärntner Krone"

column1: Klagenfurt is a popular vacation spot
column2: with mountains both to the south and north
column3: numerous parks and a series of 23 stately homes and castles on its outskirts. In summer
column4: the city is home to the Altstadtzauber (The Magic of the Old City) festival.

column1: Also located here are the University of Klagenfurt
column2: a campus of the Fachhochschule Kärnten
column4: a college of education for primary and secondary teacher training and further education of teachers as well as a college of general further education (VHS) and two institutions of further professional and vocational education (WIFI and BFI). Among other Austrian educational institutions
column5: there is a Slovene language Gymnasium (established in 1957) and a Slovene language commercial high school. Several Carinthian Slovene cultural and political associations are also based in the city
column6: including the Hermagoras Society
column7: the oldest Slovene publishing house founded in Klagenfurt in 1851.

== Sports ==

The Austrian ice-hockey record-champion EC KAC is one of the best known sports clubs in Austria. The "Eishockey Club Klagenfurter Athletiksport Club" has won the Austrian Championship 30 times and its fans come from all over Carinthia.
The Premier League Football club SK Austria Kärnten is based in Klagenfurt.
Klagenfurt hosts the Start/Finish of the Austrian Ironman Contest
column5: part of the WTC Ironman series
column6: which culminates in the Hawaii World Championships.The World (European) Rowing Championships were held on the Wörthersee in 1969.

column1: One of the FIVB's Beach Volleyball Grand Slams takes place in Klagenfurt every July and is almost always one of Austria's biggest celebrations during the year.  Beach volleyball is popular in Austria even though the country is landlocked. Austrian players Clemens Doppler
column4: who are perennial European powerhouses take part every year.  The 2009 champions of this tournament were the 2008 Beijing gold medal team from the US
column5: Phil Dalhausser and Todd Rogers.Klagenfurt also hosted three games during the UEFA Euro 2008 Championships in the recently built Hypo-Arena. Klagenfurt was also a contender for the 2006 Winter Olympics

column1: and is home to an American Football team
column3: competing in the First League of the Austrian Football League.  The Black Lions attract fans from all over Carinthia
column4: playing home games in both Klagenfurt and Villach.
